Dated 11th December 1932. IMPORTANT. I propose infoiming Shaikh Hamad that Government of India formally recognise him as Ruler of Bahrain. Grateful for immediate sanction to the step so that there may be no opening for mischiei making. This step is purely matter of form as Shaikh Hamad was recognised as his father's successor in 1901 (regret reference not on tour with me) and has been acting as Ruler since 1923 vide P.G. 13, page 64, paragraph 14. Please address your reply to Bushire ana repeat to Political Agent, Bahrain. RESIDENT. Copy forwaraed to Political Agent, Bahrain, By order. for Secretary to the Political Resiaent in the Persian Gulf, Camp, Bahrain, 11th December 1932. Kuler of sahrain,to the Political Agent, Bahrain. letter imo; 222 dated the 15th shaban 1351 ^corresponding 13th December 1932) stating that xour excellency has received telegraphic instructions to the effect that the government of mdia have recognised your friend as the ituler of eahrain, and that iour excellency is very glad to convey this good news to your friend* it is,ofcourse,due to your generous May (aod always make you advanced in prosperity and happiness, i hope you will convey my best thanks to the government of India, may ^od support its perpetual glory ahd existence. After compliments. i have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your kind% 1 Telegram Prom To lie-eated to ±1 27 Secretary of State for India, London. His Dajesty^s Government confirm your Secretary of State for India. rost copy forwaraed to the for information. political Apent, Bahrain, By order, for SecretarAo^tha Political iesiden m the iersian Gulf.COHfflflEflTIAL. N0.923-S of 1932* British Residency & Gonsulate-General Bushire, the 17th December 1932. To The Political Agent, Bahrain Subject: Accession of Shaikh Hamad Memorandum . With reference to our conversations during my recent visit to Bahrain regarding Shaikh Hamad’s accession. Shaikh Hamad as Ruler and, as arranged, you have doubtless formally informed him accordingly. I think, however, that it would be suitable if this intimation of recognition could be followed by a Kharita of congratulation from His Excellency the Viceroy, which I could present to Shaikh Hamad at a Durbar, say, in January. I enclose a copy of a pro posed Kharita modelled on the one sent by His Excellency to His Highness the present Sultan of Muscat. The Kharita would doubtless please the Shaikh, and its formal presenta tion by the Political Resident in open Durbar would mark the accession with the ceremony that is expected on such occasions. 5. Please telegraph your views, and if you concur I will take up the matter with the Government of India. 2 The Government of India have already recognised Lt.-Colonel Political Resident in the Persian Gulf.To His Excellency Shaikh Hamad bin Isa A1 Khalifa, Ruler of Bahrain and Dependencies. My esteemed friend, As Your Excellency has already been made aware the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf has received instructions to accord to Your Excellency on behalf of the Government of India, recognition as Ruler of Bahrain and Dependencies in succession to Your Excellency’s father Shaikh Isa bin Ali A1 Khalifa, Honorary Knight Commander of the Indian Empire, Companion of the Most Exalted Order of the Star of India, and I take this opportunity to offer Your Excellency my hearty congratulations on your accession to his place. I pray that Your Excellency may live long to rule over your people, and that the State of Bahrain may advance in prosperity under your guidance. I desire to express the high consideration which I entertain for Your Excellency, and to subscribe myself, Your Excellency’s sincere friend, Viceroy and Governor General of India. HE! DEHLI. Thei. COHfflDEUTIAL. U0.945-.S of 1932* British Residency & Consulate-General Bushire, the 23rd December 1932 From - The Hon’ble Lt.Colonel r.C.Fowle,C. 1'. , With reference to correspondence ending with tele gram Ko.3229, dated the 13th December 1932, from His Majesty's Secretary of State for India, I have the honour to state that I have received a letter from His Hxcellency Shaikh Hamad bin Isa al Khalifa, R ler of Bahrain, request ing that his thanks may be conveyed to the Government of India for their recognition of his succession. 1 am sending a copy of this letter to His Majesty's Secretary of State for India. + :fo:rwar<ie d to the Political Agent, Bahrain, for informa- Xe 2 . T.C.Fowle, G.B*K., Political Resident in the Persian Gulf, The Foreign Secretary to the Government of India, JSew Delhi. Subject ; Suggested Xharita to H,&. Shaikh Hamad bin Isa, Ruler of Bahrain. U r^ 1 jJV c* Sir, y I have the honour to refer to the correspondence ending with my letter No. 947-3, of 23rd December, and to enquire whether His Excellency the Viceroy would be so kind as to consider the sending of a Kharita to His Excellency Shaikh Hamad congratulating him on his accession, ( &a was done in the case of His Highness the Sultan of Muscat last January), which I could present at a Durbar on my next visit to Bahrain. The Kharita would undoubtedly please the Shaikh, and its formal presentation in open Durbar would mark his accession with the ceremony that is expected on such occasions. I enclose a suggested wording for the Kharita modelled on the one sent to the Sultan [ vide Government of India letter No. F.40-11/31, dated 22nd January 1932). I hf ve the honour to be, Sir, Your most obedient servant, Sd/- T.C.Fowle. Lieut-Col., Political Resident in the Persian Gulf. P.T.O.Copy forwarded to the Political Agent, Bahrain,DRAFT. By order, $, 1 'RESIDENT “ for Secre __ Political Resident in the Persian Gulf. > AV , Translation of letter dated the 6th, Shawal 1351 ( 1st. ^enuary 1933 ) from His Excellency Shaikh Hamad bin ’Isa al khalifa , Ruler of Bahrain addressed to Lieut* Colonel G. Loch, Political Agent, Bahrain* (?■ After compliments In the most auspicious moment I received your letter Ho.130 of 1933 the contents of which have duly Been noted- especially the tidings that His Excellency the Viceroy of India ( may God help him ) is pleased to send a hharita containing his personal congratulations to me on my access ion and that the Hon'ble the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf intends to visit Bahrain to present the Kharita to me at a formal JDarBar which he suggests to Be held in the afternoon of the 9th. February corresponding 14th. Shawal 1351. I and the people of Bahrain welcome him for conveying this good news and at the same time I am always tnaniciui to you for your kind endtevour and agree- able disposition that always Bring good news and happiness for me. May God Bestow his Blessings on Both you and me. Usual ending. (L l-i- — L&rtyU, _ —.. — » — — — ~ ■ —. ... .....c . 1 I CONFIDENTIAL. Kharita to His Ixcellency Sh4j.!ch Hamd bin Isa, Ruler of Bahrain. Sir, a L mV y With reference to your letter Ho. 9(£$-S of 1932, dated the 27th December 1932, I am directed to forward a Isharita from His Excellency the Right Honourable the E:;rl of Willingdon, P.G., G*M.S»1., G.M.I.E., G.G.M.0. , G.B.E., Viceroy and Governor General of India, for delivery to His Excellency ^iftilsh Hamad bin Isa Al Khalifa, 0.8.1., Ruler of Bahrain, at his installation and to request that you will present it, together with a suitable translation in Arab!c, to His Excellency in open Darb&r as proposed by you. 2. M# esfe&emea fi‘i«^ As lour Excellency has already been i^aae awar®, the Political Basidmt in the Persian Gulf has received instructions to accord to Tour Excellency on 'behalf of His Majesty 1 ® Government and the Government of Iru-ia, recognition as Baler of Bahrain in succession to Tour Excellency’s father, Sheikh Isa bin All ill Khalifa* Honorary Knight Oommander of the Indian Empire, Companion of the lost Exalted Order of the Star of India, and I take this o pportunlty to offer Tour Excellency my hearty congratulations on tfcjur accession to his place* I pray that Tour Excellency may live long to rule over your people, and that the State of Bahrain may advance in prosperity under your guidance* I remain, with much consideration, Tour Excellency’s sincere friend, 3d. Willingdon, Viceroy arid Governor-Gene rad of India. Hew .Delhi, (A Th e 5^ January 19 S 3 • ■19/218 0 3t> Telegram R. 1012 Political Besident, at Batirain. H«M*s. Minister, Tehran. No. T-15. hated 10th February 19S3. For information. I presented yesterday in Burhar to Shaikh of Bahrain letter of congratulation on his accession from His Excellency the Viceroy of India. Camp, Bahrain, 10th February 1933. .afcnaaa«iasaMfa»<«MiarT-‘ —iif Translation of letter dated the 14th. Shawal 1351 ( 9th. February 1933 J from His Excellency Shaixh bin Isa al Khalifa, Ruler of Bahrain addressed to His Excellency the Viceroy and Governor General of India. After compliments. I have the honour to offer my most sincere respect to Your Excellency and my heart-felt devotion and friend ship. I have received with profound pleasure Your Excellency* letter saying that the Hon*ble the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf has received instructions to accord recognition to my accession, on behalf of the Government of India as Ruler of Bahrain in succession to my late father His Excellency Shaixh Isa bin Ali a! Khali fail K.C.I.E., C.S.I., 1 also accept with thanks and pleasure your congratulations on my accession and your good wishes for me and for my country. I take the op.urtunity to express to His Excellency my firm friendship with His Britannic Majesty’s Government which has lasted since the time of fine os tors. I pray to God that our friendship \*ill continue and that it e(m£ be observed with sincerety by both sides and that honour and properity may attend His Majesty and His noble people, and X wish for you my esteemed friend a long life and perpetual happiness. In conclusion I beg Your Excellency to accept the thanks and greetings of your sincere friend. Usual Ending. ‘—'t' f 1— /j, tl-1- *70.16^- . of 195.S British asldency & Conaulate- cncral Bushire, the 17tii February 1933 From Tiie Hon* ble Colonel i.C,Fo*le, 0. political aesicient in the Persian ..ull' To The Foreign Secretary to the <»ove.rnment of In ie ?iiew Jelhi Sir ;,ith reference to the correspondence ending with / Coverniaent of inula 1 s telegram Ho*93*h of 2oth January 1933, i have the honour to end ore a translation of a letter of th&nka from iiis Excellency nhaikh Hamad to Hie xcelienqy the Viceroy for the Khar ita which Hia Excellency was kind enough to send recent visit to iihrain, at a ^axb&r held on the 7tn instant at which the l^rge number - for aura in ~ of some six hundred people were present, 11.*<,.’*'Triad*, with Captain Orabbe, the Senior Haval Officer, on board, and the survey Chip H.M.S. H Ormonde', were both on a visit to ahrain, while two Flying oats accompanying Air Commodore Cunningham, Chief of the Staff to tne Air Officer Commanding, * Iraq 0 mmand, had flown down from Baghdad on their way to iuscat. .Thus some twenty naval and oyal Air Force officere were able to be present at the Barbar. Arrangements for this function, which entailed considerable work, were made by Colonel Loch and Mr* lei grave. Financial Adviser to the ahraln Government. him 2 . I presented the Kharita to haikh hajaad during myc - 2 - 3H 5* I had expected, i s indicated in iny letter ^0.964- ^ of 22nd : eceaber l&i t, that the presentation of the 'hnrit& wo dd ce appreciated. Its reception, however, exceeded my anticipations. Shaikh liamad was indeed siost grateful for it, and l feel sore th8..t the letter which 1 enclose is a sincere express i n of his feelings, and not merely the conventional com-tunication called for by the occasion. ^he people ol Bahrain too displayed much interest in the Darfear, a crowd of some thousands collecting outaida tne Hell where it was held, while the town was ©n fete for three days. there is little doubt that the public recognition of His xcellency as uler has consolidated hie position, while he him^ self is personally popular with his subjects. It is to be regretted that - as I pointed out in my letter of l?th December last, ho.926-u - His . xcel.ency lacks those qualities which would smke him respected mad feared as a shaikh in addition to being liked as a man. 4. In the course of the speech which I made before presenting the Hharita, I took the opportunity, beside® cenve^xn^, to the atiaikh assurances of tne friendship of the Government of India arid of myself, of reviewing briefly the financial and general position of the utaW, of congratulating Hi a xceliency on certain economies which he had recently effected, and - with out being unduly pessimistic - of emphasising the fact that even further economies might be necessary in the future. It is an unfortunate fact that the number of individuals outside the Al Khalifa family who realise tne seriousness of the financial position of the htate is small* Both Colonel ' och and i there fore considered that some remark & of this tenor would be bene ficial as likely to strengthen the hand of the Bimikh with regard to such economies as he had already' effected, or which it might be necessary for his Government to carry out in the future, .... i mmmmfuture, and would carry the more weight ae being delivered on a public occasion. 1 have the honour to be, Sir, ¥ ur most obedient oervant, sd/~ T. C. Fowle, .It.-Colonel, Political evident in the lereian Gulf. ilo.l63-S of 1933. Copy with compliments forwarded to the Political Agent, Bahrain, for information. By u rder. for Secretary to the Political Kesident in the Persian Gulf.c Bahrain, leby 22, 1933 Dear Col. Loch, H. E. Shaikh Hamad has asked me to recover the letter to the Viceroy which was handed to you at the Durbar, so that it can be written in English and Arabic, there is also a slight mistake in the wording. Yours sincerely, Lieut Col. Cordon Loch, Political Agent, Bahrain. *»■**?*#* ..... . / 0 ' IsSsSS&aAss Political Agency, Baaram, the BVth January 1934. I.Q.No:C/bl Dear Colonel Fowle, lhe PhaiKh is holding some mlormal ceremonies (dances at the p alace and so lorth) on the 30th ana 31st January in commemoration of the Barber at which he receivea the Viceroy T s Khanta congratulating him on his accession. I think, that he would greatly appreciate a telegram of good wishes to reach him on the morning of the 30th January. Yours sincerely, The honourable Lieut-Colonel Y.G.e.Fowle,C.3.h., Political hesident m the !ersian Gulf,Bushire.c mmmmmmmmmmmKmi (h>\ 1 © P.R T s letter No:162-S dated 17-2-1933 to Govt of- India. PRESENTATION OP KIARITAH TO SHAIKH HAMAD. P.A. Submitted. In Para 2 the P,R states at a Darbar held on the '7th Instant'. This is incorrect as the Darbar was held on the 9th. 2. May this be pointed out please? L.O.Letter No:1072 dated 22nd February 1932 from Mr.Belgrave The letter in question and a translation thereof was handed to by P.R when he was here. Itfhas since been forwarded to the Government of India. , . I spoke to tne Adviser ana tola nim inat His Excellency Shaikh Hamad’s letter to His Excellency tne Viceroy naa oeen sent on. Apparently wnat tne Shaixn wisnea to alter was tne line about 'accord recognition to my accession,on oenaif of t ne Gover nment oi India ..'.asine naa suosequentiy noticed tnat His Excellency the Viceroy naa written 'accom to Your Excellency on oenaif of His Majesty’s Government ana tne Government of India. I said tnat I tnougnt tnat nis idea was correct out tnat I was uouotful wnetner it would ue sou/ina now to alter ms letter. This lile should go with me to Bushire. o. Issue D.O.below. c ^ £*?? 7IAL. I understand that at a recent interview between the Secretary to the Kon'ble the Political Resident (Captain Gastrell) >: and the Governor of Bushire,the Governor said that he had heard a good deal about the ceremonies at Bahrain and enquired whether itvwas true that the status of the Shaikh had been altered,as he understood that the word ? melek T had been used in the speeches. | Captain Gastrell assured him that no alteration had been maae in the status of the Shaikh. 2. The word ’melek* was not,of course,used in the Hon T ble the Political Residents speech but it was usea in the course oi Shaikh Muhammad’s speech. The word is,however,not uncommonly used by local people in referring to the Shaikh. B. What the Governor may have got hold of is the fact that Shaikh Muhammad quoted in his speech an extract from a long poem of him,regarding the expulsion of Persians from Bahrain. 4.Another curious matter about which we must obtain full iniormation is the fact that it has got about in certain quarters, j amongst others the Shiah Wadhis,that the Ilon’ble the Political ^esiaent had said in his speech that the Government had agreed to forego the annual subsidy which was paid to them by the Bahrain Government and that it would no longer be paid, it is quite obvious that the basis of this idea is the reference to the customs duties,but it seems necessary to take steps to combat the idea of Bahrain ever having paid a subsidy or tribute. I have given Mr.Belgrave a copy of the Arabic of the Hon’ble the Political resident’s speech to show to the Shiah wadhis. h. I should like the Indian Assistant to make discreet enquiries as to whether this idea is at all widespread. b. The Indian Assistant should see this Note in confidence 2S-2-iyo3. P .A. Heference paras 4 & 5. .With whomsoever I have met and

location.physicalLocation: British Library: India Office Records and Private Papers

titleInfo.title: '31/2 RECOGNITION OF H.E. Sk. HAMAD bin ISA KHALIFAH AS RULER OF BAHRAIN.'

physicalDescription.extent: The papers in the file are arranged chronologically from the front to the rear of the file.

Foliation: the main foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 46; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. An additional foliation sequence is present in parallel between ff 2-45; these numbers are also written in pencil, but are not circled, and are located in the same position as the main sequence.

mods.abstract: The file contains correspondence regarding the formal recognition of Shaikh Hamad as Ruler of Bahrain by the Government of India and the presentation to him of a kharitaby the Political Resident, Bushire on behalf of Freeman Freeman-Thomas Willingdon,Viceroy and Governor-General of India.The English version of the Kharita is found on folio 29 and an Arabic version on folio 30.
